Our resellers

OpenAthens works with a range of resellers worldwide. We are very proud of our global collaborations as they assist us in supporting our customers worldwide.

EBSCO, Worldwide

EBSCO Information Services are a major reseller of OpenAthens to library customers worldwide. As part of their service to setup and onboard our library customers, EBSCO reach out to resource providers so that patrons can connect to content and services via the OpenAthens Federation.

EBSCO is the leading provider of e-journal, e-book and e-journal package and print subscriptions, e-resource management tools, full-text and secondary databases, and related services for all types of libraries and research organizations. Our software integrates with other EBSCO services such as EBSCO Discovery Service and FOLIO.

TDNet, Worldwide

TDNet are a reseller of OpenAthens to library customers worldwide, with customers in the academic, corporate, government,  healthcare and public library markets. As part of their service to setup and onboard our library customers, TDNet reach out to resource providers so that end users can access content and services via the OpenAthens Federation.

TDNet provide a range of innovative tools and services to help libraries and information centres to effectively discover, access, manage and maintain their electronic resources.

TotemGuard, Spain

TotemGuard provide customers in the education and healthcare industries with the tools needed to automate the management, support and protection of their IT resources. TotemGuard helps its customers manage access to IT resources, allowing them to provide better service to their users while reducing operating costs.

What systems do we integrate with?

OpenAthens Compass seamlessly integrates with multiple local directory systems such as Azure/Entra, Okta, Shibboleth etc. We support a variety of integration methods such as SAML, OIDC, LDAP and have a REST-based API for those who want to develop a custom integration.

Connections

If your organization already has a user directory storing user account and usernames and passwords, OpenAthens Compass is able to connect securely with this data. Single sign-on is easily established along with the benefits of the OpenAthens Compass administrative area. Some of the options are listed below.

SAML

OpenAthens Compass can connect to SAML sources such as Microsoft Entra, Google Apps, OneLog, Shibboleth, and others so that you do not have to issue personal accounts for your users. As well as the ability to use local accounts instead of maintaining a separate set of credentials, access to federated resources that already involve discovery (identifying the users’ home organization) will take the user directly to your SAML login.

ADFS

Connect directly to ADFS (Active Directory Federation Services) so that you do not have to issue personal accounts for your users. As well as the ability to use local accounts instead of maintaining a separate set of credentials, access to federated resources that already involve discovery (identifying the users’ home organization) will take the user directly to your ADFS login.

LDAP

Connect directly to an LDAP server so that you do not have to issue personal accounts for your users. Anything that uses standard LDAP protocols is acceptable so this works well with ActiveDirectory too. As well as the ability to use local accounts instead of maintaining a separate set of credentials, access to federated resources that already involve discovery (identifying the users’ home organization) will take the user directly to your LDAP login at our authentication point – no further discovery is required.

API

The OpenAthens Compass local authentication API can be used to log your users into the system based on credentials stored in any system you can gain programmatic access to.  You will be required to implement some code at your end.

SirsiDynix

OpenAthens Compass can connect to a SirsiDynix system using its Symphony or Horizon API so that you do not have to issue personal accounts for your users.

CAS

OpenAthens Compass can connect to CAS (Client Access Server) so that you do not have to issue personal accounts for your users. You will need a CAS server with SAML support enabled.

OIDC

Along with SAML, OIDC is fast becoming the new dominant  standard in federated identity. Adding support for OIDC enables OpenAthens Compass to connect to a wider range of identity systems and directories which organizations are increasingly starting to use.

Evergreen ILS

The Evergreen ILS connector allows users to log in to OpenAthens Compass with their Evergreen credentials.

Applications we work with include the below and many more

"The ease of use and flexibility of OpenAthens [Compass] has been invaluable to Aston University in enabling us to transform the service we provide to students, staff and our partner institutions."

The benefits of an integrated library system

OpenAthens Compass is designed to integrate with other existing library systems and directories.  This comes with benefits including user efficiency for students, researchers and staff.

Library systems integration success stories

How Lean Library integration simplifies user journeys

Lean Library is a powerful browser plug-in that reliably and seamlessly extends the library resources, services and branding directly into the users’ workflow, wherever they are. Learn how Lean Library integrates with OpenAthens Compass to transform the remote access experience for your users.

Chalmers University Library creates easy access for walk-in users

Hear how Chalmers University of Technology integrated OpenAthens Compass with EBSCO’s FOLIO open-source library service to increase ease of access and support logins for various user groups, including community walk-in users.

Clarkson College transforms library services

OpenAthens Compass integrated into OneLogin in just one hour to provide transparent single sign-on authentication to library resources. The director of library services handled all content and publisher set up herself, calling on OpenAthens and EBSCO when she needed advice.

What publishers and service providers are we compatible with?

Search our database of publishers and service providers that are compatible with the OpenAthens service. Filter on those that are in identity federations, or compatible with the OpenAthens Redirector or managed proxy.

Increase your efficiency with the OpenAthens Reporting API

Forget about spending long hours delving into usage data and user activity to understand which resources are being used and how.

Our Reporting API add-on is a time-saving tool created with librarians at heart. It offers data granularity to suit your needs, helping you understand users, improve retention and manage your budget.

Key features and benefits

Time saving Designed to make processes easier and save you time. You can automate reports, easily download data and even use external BI tools to visualize it.

Time saving

Automated report downloads Reduce manual effort and optimizing operational efficiency.

Customizable reports Create reports and present your data-insights in your preferred BI software. Combine it with other data sources to better understand student engagement.

Customizable reports

Enables in-depth analysis Our Reporting API tool offers granular details on the reportable attributes and includes reporting data on Restrictive Mode turn-aways, providing better understanding about the resources users are trying to access without the right permissions and subscriptions.

Our Reporting API tool offers granular details on the reportable attributes and includes reporting data on Restrictive Mode turn-aways, providing better understanding about the resources users are trying to access without the right permissions and subscriptions.

User insights Identify users, their IP address, and locations by non-personally identifiable information.

Identify misuse Easily identify and address potential misuse.

Increase retention Our Reporting API tool helps you make data-driven decisions and identify where to allocate your budget to increase user retention.

Enhanced reporting features Our reporting API tool offers two levels of granularity: Aggregated data: mirrors the data in the OpenAthens reporting interface (aggregated by hour, day, or month). Raw data: unaggregated authentication and resource usage data. It also integrates with business intelligence software such as Tableau or Power BI and is data is available in CSV file format.

Enhanced reporting features

Our reporting API tool offers two levels of granularity:

Aggregated data: mirrors the data in the OpenAthens reporting interface (aggregated by hour, day, or month).

Raw data: unaggregated authentication and resource usage data.

It also integrates with business intelligence software such as Tableau or Power BI and is data is available in CSV file format.

What is the Reporting API?

The OpenAthens Reporting API was launched in 2020 as an add-on to our library product interface and soon became the go-to tool when viewing resource access data. While it was already a powerful tool, we have received feedback that we could improve it further, so our team started working with a small group of customers to come up with an enhanced tool in 2024.

The Reporting API not only helps you automate report downloads, combine data with other institutional information, and visualize it effortlessly using external business intelligence tools like Tableau or Power BI. It now also provides access to raw, unaggregated authentication and resource usage data, meaning more granular details, including specific times, locations, identifiers, activities, and other reportable attributes.

In our enhanced API, you will also find reporting data on Restrictive Mode turn-aways that provide you with a better understanding of the resources patrons are trying to access without the right permissions and subscriptions.

Who can use it?

The Reporting API is an add-on to our library product, so you must be an OpenAthens Compass customer to benefit from it. Speak to your account manager to find out more.

Reporting API features help leading research library demonstrate value

For years, the J. Murrey Atkins Library at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNC Charlotte) has used the OpenAthens Reporting API to unlock library usage statistics and inform planning decisions. Find out how enhancements to our Reporting API have helped them gather evidence of how engagement with library resources boosts student success.

Anglia Ruskin University sees increase in student retention with OpenAthens Reporting API

Check out our case study with Anglia Ruskin University (ARU) and find out how the original Reporting API was helping ARU before the 2024 enhancements. We also have a webinar recording with ARU and Nescot College during which we discuss the importance of reporting and the key metrics you need to look out for, whether it is to identify bottlenecks, improve services or better allocate budgets.

Want to find out more?

Your account manager will be able to tell you more about our Reporting API add-on for OpenAthens Compass.

Cost-effective authentication gets the library future-ready at Gwanda State University

29 September 2025

										• Faitai Bella Ballo, Product marketing officer

This young university has invested in OpenAthens Connect to help it realize its vision.

Gwanda State University (GSU) in Zimbabwe was established in 2016, providing heritage-based education in animal and veterinary sciences, ecosystems restoration, environmental engineering and more. Recently, its library was on the lookout for a cost-effective authentication solution to underpin its strategy to be driving cutting-edge learning, research and innovation by 2030.

Extensive library resources

GSU has around 500 students and nearly 400 staff. They all depend on the library’s diverse, rich digital content – including journals, e-books, databases, conference proceedings and video lectures. And they don’t just need these in the library. They need them right across GSU’s two campuses, in their homes and residential hostels and when they’re out doing practicals. But with no authentication solution in place, accessing the resources meant remembering multiple passwords and navigating a variety of time-consuming login processes.

It was time, then, to focus on GSU’s priorities to enhance user experience and support changing approaches to learning and teaching in an increasingly digital world.

Cost-effective authentication

Like many universities in Africa, GSU was keen to adopt a simple solution rather than one developed for complex, larger organizations.

“We must provide a seamless user experience, and support remote and blended learning"

“We also needed to strengthen information security through robust authentication standards. And, importantly, we needed a solution that was more affordable than many products on the market.”

Smooth implementation

They surveyed the options carefully and we’re delighted to say they chose ours, because it’s secure, user friendly and more affordable than comparable products. Using the guidance we provided, GSU Library’s IT staff managed the OpenAthens Connect implementation themselves, with support from the wider university’s IT team. It was straightforward, and updates and maintenance are routinely handled through what the library staff describe as “seamless communication and collaboration” between the library, the publisher and our support desk.

His top tips for institutions thinking about adopting OpenAthens Connect are:

Engage your information and communications technology (ICT) department early and explain clearly what permissions or support you’ll need

Make use of the detailed documentation and support resources provided by OpenAthens, to make the process easier

Communicate with staff and users about upcoming changes, so they know what to expect and why it matters

Benefits

GSU are confident that, for them, OpenAthens Connect hits the ‘sweet spot’. They’re enjoying high-quality, robust and cost-effective authentication and giving users seamless access to licensed electronic resources both on and off campus. Crucially, they’ve achieved it even with the budget and resource constraints that many institutions have.

The library has gathered user feedback in surveys and focus groups. It is very positive, and summed up neatly by one user:

“It feels like the library is right here with me, even when I’m off campus.”

“Users especially appreciate how much easier it is to access resources off campus with a single sign-on and many value the consistent login experience across multiple different publishers’ platforms"

“This kind of feedback has reassured us that implementing OpenAthens Connect has genuinely improved access and supported our users’ needs.”

Faith in the solution! Efficient authentication is now invisible and seamless at Oak Hill College

29 September 2025

										• Faitai Bella Ballo, Product marketing officer

In David Fordyce’s interview for his role as college librarian he was asked “how would you provide a service where students could access all our resources in one place?” Now the interviewers have their answer

Oak Hill is a specialist college in Southgate, London, with one of the finest theological libraries in south-east England, open 24/7. It has 55,000 print and electronic resources from several vendors – and around 100 online users, many living on site.

Efficient authentication is essential for the library and until a couple of years ago they managed it via IP authentication or sign in with Google. IP authentication usually served users on campus, but it didn’t meet the needs of people learning or working elsewhere.

Finding a more efficient authentication solution

Sorting out the authentication issue was the first step to answering the interviewers’ question. But as a small, specialist college with a modest budget affordability was essential.

He asked other libraries in Oak Hill’s sector what they were using and found it was usually authentication via OpenAthens. As a result, Oak Hill was among the first to join the pilot for OpenAthens Connect, our new core features product developed for less complex organizations.

The set-up process, says David, was “straightforward”. He simply gathered a list of their resource providers and these were set up in the OpenAthens Connect product. Now, our solution connects the college’s library users to online resources through an identity hub entity – a cost-effective, simple option for smaller institutions.

Fit for the future

Oak Hill’s library has seen big improvements as a result, and is in good shape for more in the coming months.

“Today’s students expect everything to just click through,” comments David.

With our single sign-on solution everything does, and students and staff can access library resources wherever they learn and work. David is saving lots of time too, because previously he was spending huge amounts of it setting up workarounds and manual logins.

Now the ‘efficient authentication’ box is ticked off on David’s to-do list, and he’s on phase two of his plan.

In autumn 2025 the library will implement EBSCO Discovery Service to bring all its resources together in one place.

“I identified EBSCO as the best discovery service for our specialized needs but there was no point having it without getting the authentication right first,” says David.

This latest development will support a new departure for the college – its first fully online course. At this point Oak Hill will move to our premium product OpenAthens Compass , which offers additional analytical tools and other features. Compass will be implemented by our partner EBSCO as part of their discovery service offer.

“I want to have the additional features at that point,” David comments. “These products seem tricky to grasp, especially authentication because it’s largely invisible. But it has been possible to get the purchase approved because the college’s managers can see the benefits – and trust that there’s more to come.”

We designed OpenAthens Connect to fill a gap and make sure that all institutions, regardless of their size and budget, can access secure, seamless authentication without technical complexities. Oak Hill’s experience with Connect shows how easy it is to achieve, and the multiple benefits it brings.

A simplified authentication solution that connects students to quality resources

29 September 2025

										• Faitai Bella Ballo, Product marketing officer

About Derwentside College and the OpenAthens Connect pilot

Until about two years ago Derwentside College’s library used an IP-based authentication system to give its learners access to digital resources. That meant being on campus to make use of them. When working off-site, learners often made online searches that found sub-standard content.

The OpenAthens Connect pilot gave Derwentside’s library a perfect opportunity to implement a secure, simple authentication solution that works any time, anywhere. OpenAthens Connect is designed for less complex organizations like Derwentside. It provides a cost-effective, core federated access solution. By enabling single sign-on it eliminates the need for complex multiple login processes and makes using high-quality licensed digital resources the quickest, easiest option for learners.

Derwentside College’s library supports apprentices and work-based learners in placements across much of England. So it needs an authentication solution that is simple, effective and hassle-free.

Until recently the 600 learners on its campus in Consett, County Durham used the college’s IP-based authentication system to access digital resources, including Jisc’s e-books for FE collection. The 2,500+ learners off-site had no such access to online resources. But, often, they weren’t using traditional books from the college or its training providers either.

“We struggle to get learners to use books, they think Google has the answer to everything,” says Angela Cummings, cloud applications and IT support officer at the college’s campus in Consett, County Durham.

“Learners expect to work digitally so we must give them the right kind of resources – ones that are accurate, up to date and quality assured.”

Simplified authentication in action

Looking for a way to authenticate users that makes it easy for them to learn any time, anywhere, Derwentside joined the pilot for the new OpenAthens product. Connect is our cost-effective, simplified authentication solution for organizations that don’t need lots of customization or advanced analytics features.

Angela says they got started on the pilot quickly:

"It’s probably one of the easiest systems I’ve ever had to set up."

Not surprisingly, a few links didn’t work at first. But these were all resolved rapidly. And because OpenAthens Connect is cloud-based the college didn’t need to invest in any extra hardware or software. It is simply integrated with their Microsoft account and we take care of maintenance and updates.

Time and cost savings

Derwentside College’s library team is small so it’s a big bonus that OpenAthens Connect is saving them time on managing IT issues – the previous authentication solution often caused failures that frustrated both learners and staff. Angela says these savings will grow as the library expands its focus on digital in place of paper-based books and journals. The college is confident to do this now it has an effective authentication system in place.

Improved user experience

For learners on vocational programmes OpenAthens Connect isn’t just better than using one of the big commercial search engines – it’s easier as well. It simplifies discovery. Single sign-on authenticates them and gives them seamless access to quality resources and their own saved, annotated searches so they can do their best work.

Do learners like the improvements? It seems so – the proof comes from the analytics tools built into Connect, as Angela comments:

“We can track how resources are being used. We know, for example, that our health and social care learners are using their e-books in almost every session.”

Join the OpenAthens Federation, a globally trusted network

Reach more customers worldwide by easily connecting your content and services with the OpenAthens Federation

What is a Federation?

A federation is a collaborative network of organizations that agree to share resources and information securely. By joining a federation, service providers and publishers can allow their users to access a wide range of services and content using a single set of login credentials. This simplifies the authentication process and enhances security.

The OpenAthens Federation offers great flexibility. Join us with any SAML single sign-on solution and we will handle all the technical complexities for you.

An international network connecting different industries

The OpenAthens Federation is the only one in the world that allows participation of publishers or service providers from any country or sector.

Joining the federation, you become part of a global network with over 3,000 members from diverse industries, including academia, healthcare and corporate markets.

What do you get with the OpenAthens Federation?

Complaints

We follow the Jisc complaints procedure for any issues relating to our OpenAthens services.

Complaints process

Send your complaint by email to help@jisc.ac.uk.

You’ll receive an automatic response with a ticket number as reference.

The complaint manager will conduct an initial analysis and identify a complaint coordinator, they will then agree on roles and responsibilities in handling the complaint.

Our internal complaints team will be notified and you will be updated within 1 working day of logging your complaint.

The complaint coordinator will investigate your complaint and they will implement resolution actions, as well as seeking to determine the cause and if similar problems could or do occur.

The complaint manager will work with the complaint coordinator to ensure all parties are kept informed throughout the complaint process.

Your complaint will be seen through to a resolution. You’ll receive a resolution response within 20 working days.

Preventative and improvement actions will be captured and used to update known risks and to support quality improvements.

What is the Jisc complaint procedure?

Welcome to OpenAthens

OpenAthens is a leader in authentication, making secure, remote access to resources simple and reliable for organizations worldwide.

With 30 years' experience and trusted by academic, healthcare, and corporate research institutions, we provide dedicated solutions for librarians and publishers. By removing barriers to knowledge, we enable seamless, single sign-on (SSO) – meeting your users where their journey begins.

We’re SSO pioneers with 30 years in the business

Transfers to resources 5 billion and counting

Trusted by 3,200+ organizations worldwide

Used in over 80 countries

Our resellers

OpenAthens works with a range of resellers worldwide. We are very proud of our global collaborations as they assist us in supporting our customers worldwide.

EBSCO, Worldwide

EBSCO Information Services are a major reseller of OpenAthens to library customers worldwide. As part of their service to setup and onboard our library customers, EBSCO reach out to resource providers so that patrons can connect to content and services via the OpenAthens Federation.

EBSCO is the leading provider of e-journal, e-book and e-journal package and print subscriptions, e-resource management tools, full-text and secondary databases, and related services for all types of libraries and research organizations. Our software integrates with other EBSCO services such as EBSCO Discovery Service and FOLIO.

TDNet, Worldwide

TDNet are a reseller of OpenAthens to library customers worldwide, with customers in the academic, corporate, government,  healthcare and public library markets. As part of their service to setup and onboard our library customers, TDNet reach out to resource providers so that end users can access content and services via the OpenAthens Federation.

TDNet provide a range of innovative tools and services to help libraries and information centres to effectively discover, access, manage and maintain their electronic resources.

TotemGuard, Spain

TotemGuard provide customers in the education and healthcare industries with the tools needed to automate the management, support and protection of their IT resources. TotemGuard helps its customers manage access to IT resources, allowing them to provide better service to their users while reducing operating costs.

Need support?

Informes

Ahorra tiempo y facilita el proceso de toma de decisiones utilizando los informes granulares de Compass para realizar un seguimiento del uso, controlar el acceso y ayudar a evitar el uso indebido. Para mayor nivel de detalle, también puedes activar la función API de informes.

Obtén estadísticas detalladas y personalizables que te ayuden a tomar decisiones informadas sobre suscripciones y renovaciones, a la vez que te ayudan a evitar el uso indebido del acceso. Descarga informes y compártelos con tus usuarios cuando sea necesario.

Saca el máximo partido a nuestra funcionalidad de informes

Identifica qué informes pueden ser útiles para ti Te recomendamos dedicar un tiempo a revisar y planificar qué informes serán más útiles para tu organización. Por ejemplo, se pueden generar informes que muestren zonas calientes (hot zones), es decir, momentos con mayor probabilidad de acceso a los contenidos. Esto puede ayudarte a planificar mejor los recursos humanos en tu biblioteca para asegurar suficiente personal disponible.

Funcionalidad de informes

Soluciones personalizadas para bibliotecas tan únicas como la tuya

Mapea cualquier atributo

OpenAthens Compass puede reconocer y mapear cualquier atributo cuando las cuentas de usuario son creadas desde un directorio externo como ADFS o Azure AD. Si deseas ampliar tus capacidades de generación de informes, deberás especificar tus requisitos a tu equipo de TI, ya que ellos probablemente tendrán que realizar algunas configuraciones de su lado.. Estaremos encantados de ayudarte con la configuración necesaria en el lado administrativo de OpenAthens.

Personalízalo como necesites

Atributos como el puesto de trabajo, el centro de costo, el departamento o la titulación pueden personalizarse en función de tus necesidades específicas y capacidades técnicas. Esto se configura desde el área de administración mediante el editor de esquemas, marcando los atributos como “informables”.

Informes y privacidad

También puedes generar informes sobre la actividad de usuarios individuales, pero antes de hacerlo, ten en cuenta la privacidad de tus usuarios. Nuestra documentación sobre Informes y Privacidad te ayudará con el proceso.

Visualización de datos

Sabemos lo importante que es la elaboración de informes para las bibliotecas, tanto para hacer seguimiento del uso como para supervisar el acceso. Los informes se presentan con gráficos visuales mejorados, más allá del formato puramente textual, lo que facilita su comprensión por parte de diferentes perfiles dentro de tu organización.

Existen dos tipos principales de informes:

Informes de cuentas

Incluyen tipos de cuentas, totales de autenticaciones, ubicaciones de cuentas y cualquier otro elemento personalizado que desees analizar.

Informes de acceso a recursos

Analizan a qué recursos acceden los usuarios autenticados y pueden desglosarse por cualquier atributo que desees controlar, como el uso por departamento, para detectar posibles áreas en las que se necesite más formación o apoyo para fomentar el acceso. La interfaz de informes, llamada Data Explorer, permite definir qué informes deseas generar y qué atributos quieres que se incluyan, como escala temporal, unidades de medida, agrupaciones y más.

El nivel de detalle que necesitas para orientar tu camino.

Nuestro complemento de informes, Reporting API, es una herramienta que ahorra tiempo y ha sido creada pensando en los bibliotecarios. Ofrece una granularidad de datos, un nivel de detalle, que se adapta a tus necesidades, ayudándote a comprender a los usuarios, mejorar la retención y gestionar tu presupuesto.

Una solución a medida para cada biblioteca, en cada paso del camino

Para sacar el máximo partido a las opciones de informes disponibles, debes personalizar los informes en función de tus necesidades. Esto significa que debes asegurarte de que las cuentas de usuario contienen toda la información relevante que deseas analizar o utilizar como referencia en tus informes.

OpenAthens Compass 101: Una guía para nuestros bibliotecarios – Enlaces redireccionables (Redirector)

29 April 2020

										• Andy Anderson, data analyst

Un enlace redireccionable (Redirector) es una forma sencilla de crear un enlace WAYFless. Un enlace WAYFless identifica de dónde proviene el usuario, por lo que el recurso no necesita preguntarlo. Esto facilita el acceso a tus usuarios.

El Redirector permite añadir la dirección del artículo o sección del recurso al final de un prefijo coherente. El prefijo es específico para tu organización. El Redirector sabe qué partes debe añadir en el enlace WAYFless para que todo funcione en segundo plano en la dirección de destino.

¿Cómo será el prefijo?

El prefijo tendrá un aspecto como este:

https://go.openathens.net/redirector/yourdomain.net?url=

Al ser un prefijo, puedes utilizarlo en muchos entornos que admiten servidores proxy, como los resolutores de enlaces. La única limitación es que algunos recursos no son compatibles con el Redirector. Pero la buena noticia es que cada vez son más los recursos que sí lo son. A estos recursos los llamamos “redireccionables” cuando hablamos del Redirector. Son los más adecuados para su uso con resolutores de enlaces, ya que dirigen al usuario directamente a la página de destino especificada. Para que un recurso sea redireccionable debe admitir acceso WAYFless y enlaces profundos (también llamados enlaces a nivel de artículo). Hay varias formas de saber si un recurso es compatible las cuales puedes encontrar en nuestro sitio de documentación del Redirector.

Contamos con un generador de enlaces del Redirector para que puedas crear tus propios enlaces. El generador de enlace codifica la URL de destino y la añade al final de una dirección de prefijo específica de tu dominio. Este formato permite que este tipo de enlace sustituya a una dirección proxy en herramientas de portales, como catálogos de bibliotecas o resolutores de enlaces.

Nuestro último seminario web “101” trata sobre los enlaces redireccionables (Redirector). Puedes ver la grabación en nuestro canal de YouTube.

¿Necesita más información?

Para más información, consulte la documentación en línea o el curso intermedio en nuestra VLE.

Benefits of a managed service

22 February 2022

										• Lauren Harding, Senior digital marketing manager

A managed service providers platform without the heavy lifting

Small and medium-sized academic and scientific publishers are adopting single sign-on for their platforms in increasing numbers. Single sign-on (federated access) came into sharper focus during the COVID-19 lockdowns. It is an effective way for publishers to give library staff and end users seamless, reliable access to content while also preserving their personal privacy. It also provides safe, secure authentication.

But if your organization hasn’t taken the plunge yet, what kind of single sign-on solution do you need? An open source, non-proprietary one that you install, host and manage yourselves? Or a managed, cloud-based solution that does the hard work for you?

Open source or fully managed?

It’s a fundamental question. And with budgets always under scrutiny, open source options like Shibboleth look appealing because they are free for publishers to use. But that doesn’t make them low cost. You need to pay a subscription to access technical support and will almost certainly have to do (or arrange) the set-up and implementation yourselves. If you haven’t got in-house SAML skills – most publishers haven’t – that means either recruiting specialist staff or outsourcing the project. With SAML skills in high demand and short supply, that could prove expensive.

According to our business development manager, Kieran Prince, a realistic assessment of the cost of an open source solution should take a couple of major factors into account:

“Time is probably the biggest cost to consider. Time to develop, test and launch a solution, often with no guarantee of success. And then you will have ongoing maintenance to factor in. In addition, you’ll probably need a host server, which incurs its own ongoing maintenance and licensing costs.”

A fully managed, cloud-based solution such as OpenAthens allows you to get started with single sign-on faster. It also saves you money on development time and bought-in expertise and infrastructure.

“Our SAML specialists do the tricky technical stuff. In some cases a publisher could be set up on OpenAthens and ready to go in a month or so,” “It usually it takes a bit longer though. That’s because publishers are busy people and it can take them time to get their systems ready for us.”

It’s also worth thinking about who hosts your platform. If your product is on a self-service platform like GoDaddy or WordPress, the only method of supporting SAML will be via third-party plugins, which the host won’t help to implement or support. A managed service like OpenAthens will take care of this, although you may need to take advantage of our additional consultancy offer to do that. We work with third party hosts regularly on behalf of our customers. We smooth out any wrinkles and ensure they can deliver the same high quality single sign-on experience.

User experience

What’s more, SAML contractors who don’t have experience of working with digital publishers can leave customers with an open source solution that frustrates content users. Our former key client services manager Phil Leahy has seen that happen:

“Compared with open source, a managed service is more consistently applied. Features such as a clean login user journey and WAYFless/deep linking are must-have features for most library professionals. But they may not be considerations for developers who are unfamiliar with working with academic libraries.”

Users lose patience if access is slow or glitchy and look for alternative, possibly dubious, ways to access the material they want.

Added value for providers

All in all, OpenAthens takes care of the heavy lifting, so you don’t have to. It also brings other benefits that make daily life less stressful and help you sleep better.

For one thing, as a fully managed service our service desk is staffed by specialists between 7am and 10pm Monday to Friday. We make sure queries are dealt with swiftly. OpenAthens is also stable, with 24/7 monitoring and stringent targets for availability. If there are connectivity, security or other concerns we will identify and resolve them, often without users being aware that there was ever an issue.

Advice and support come as part of the package and are there when you need them. We also offer consultancy if you’d like more help.

Improving the impact of your resources

And lastly, we’ve talked extensively about setting up single sign-on to improve user experience for end users, but let’s not forget that you also need to maximise the reach and impact of your resources. When you sign up to OpenAthens you join our identity federation. It is the only one in the world that enables participation from authenticated users in any country or sector. That means it can bring your content to academic, scientific and commercial audiences around the globe.

Are you a  provider looking to find out more about what a managed service could do for your platform?

Drop an email to Kieran.prince@openathens.net

Health check service for publishers and service providers

Is your platform just ticking along or is it time to make some improvements? Our health check service can help get your service running more smoothly and improve user experience.

Time for a user experience health check?

Is user experience missing from your publishing cycle ? Are researchers and learners getting a bad deal when it comes to navigating and accessing content on your platform? Concerned about people turning to piracy sites and other work-arounds to access your content? Or maybe you want to increase use of your digital resources and give users the best possible online experience?

We offer a health check service which complements our existing range of products and services. Led by our experienced technical consultants, we’ll help you to identify where you can simplify and enhance your user’s online journey.

What's included in the health check?

Our audit will cover:

Users experience of contacting your support/ subscriptions team

Help documentation related to federated access

User journey to login through federated access

User login experience, including language and terminology at login

Ease and consistency of language and messaging

Creating direct links to journals and other content

Personalization eg. tied to federated login or separate credentials

Our report will outline key problem areas, technical recommendations related to your OpenAthens implementation and the best possible SSO scenario.

We’ll act like a secret shopper and do a follow up ‘spot check’ to ensure everything is working as it should. This will be at a time agreed with you. The spot check will be at a time agreed with you and after you’ve implemented our recommendations.

User experience

Five tips for improving online research experience

We study student’s behavior to improve our single sign-on products and want to share some of the findings with the wider academic community. Our top tips can help publishers provide more relevant, flexible and timely content and improve research experience.

Recommendations for improved user experience

Researchers and learners struggle to navigate access to academic content. It’s often a difficult, confusing and inconsistent journey.  Our webinar pinpoints areas where providers who offer single-sign-on institutional access can improve the experience for users associated with a library.

UX recommendations for improved user experience

Built on the RA21 recommended practices , we outline our top ten UX recommendations for improved access to academic content.

Your work is done as soon as the internal directories are connected to OpenAthens , and permissions are set. Colleagues and customers will come and go, but only those who remain within the corporate directories will have access. Use existing OpenAthens user directories to control access for individual users.

What is it?

It is an extension to the existing product that enables you to provide simple and secure access for your colleagues and key customers, even if they are not part of the OpenAthens Federation nor use SAML authentication.

This time-saving resource allows you to connect multiple external institutions and corporates, who all have their own security and privacy policies to adhere to.

And the best part… It is easy to add this onto your existing OpenAthens subscription.

Who is it suitable for?

Publishers short on time to maintain internal access systems to enable internal staff to access content

Publishers with a 3 rd party platform host who does not set up 1:1 SAML connections on your behalf

Publishers with small customers that don’t have SAML

Universities that publish content and also have library users

Would you like more information?

By using our new add-on for publishers, you can easily extend OpenAthens and open the door to your content with control and convenience, benefiting both your own company and your major customers, saving time and resources.

Zero disruption to users as Financial Times migrates to Keystone

04 September 2020

										• Sophie Allen, marketing officer

As a world-renowned news organization , the Financial Times (FT) recognizes the importance of keeping its digital users engaged. So, to help streamline access and improve engagement levels among its users in universities and libraries, it offers access via single sign-on (SSO).

Thanks to federated access management, users from this important Financial Times customer base can access content using sign-in credentials from their home organization – which streamlines access and helps keep users logging in.

The challenge

Until recently, the FT used OpenAthens SP2 to manage federated access. But with the deprecation of SP2 in May 2020, it needed to find a new solution that could be implemented by this deadline – and cause zero disruption to users while maintaining the benefits of streamlined access.

"When there is breaking news, it’s essential that we maintain quick and seamless access to FT content online, ensuring that the URLs we give to customers aren’t broken and continue to work"

The solution

Acting on a November 2019 email about the deprecation of SP2, the FT decided to migrate to OpenAthens’s cloud-based solution, Keystone, as quickly as it could.

“OpenAthens assured us that if we migrated to Keystone, the user experience wouldn’t change, and this was important for us,” says Elena. “So we didn’t have to think twice, as we already had good relations with OpenAthens.”

As planning for implementation began, the next challenge was that the FT needed detailed help in understanding how Keystone works – so it could be reassured that front-end functionality would not change. That’s because, while SP2 uses SAML, Keystone is based on OpenID Connect – so for the FT, it was not only a migration, but the implementation of a new product.

“We needed to combine OpenAthens’s knowledge of Keystone and our knowledge of how we integrated the existing SP2 solution. Keystone may be a ‘black box’ solution, but to implement it we needed to analyse it technically.”

It soon became clear that a support ticket would not be sufficient to give the FT the understanding it needed, so its team asked for a technical workshop – and OpenAthens quickly organised this.

“They showed us demos, and we showed demos of how SP2 worked on our side, and both teams improved their knowledge,” says Elena.

For the migration itself, the FT also asked for someone from OpenAthens to be online in case something went wrong. “OpenAthens agreed, so we had someone on duty personally when we were migrating the production environment from the old to the new.”

Benefits and results

The result, for the Financial Times, was a successful and timely migration, in advance of the May 2020 deadline, with no disruption to users – which was what it had planned for.

At the same time, the team was glad that implementation was completed in early lockdown due to the Covid-19 pandemic – because at that time the FT was seeing a big increase in the number of logins.

“The unusual circumstances made it even more critical for our SSO functionality to be working perfectly,” says Krum Bakalsky, senior engineer in the FT team .

After the migration, too, the FT appreciated the benefits of having a cloud-based, lightweight solution hosted by OpenAthens, as opposed to the on-premises deployment it had previously.

“We don’t have to provision or maintain the service, so if OpenAthens find bugs or add a new feature, we consume this as a service"

The team was grateful to be spared the complexities of SAML. “SAML is a relatively odd specification that’s inconsistent across implementations, with every vendor having their own tips and tricks,” says Krum. “If we don’t have SAML, it saves quite a lot of hassle for us.”

“This way we get a more robust and more stable service – and it’s maintained by OpenAthens,” adds Teodor Shaterov, technology lead in the same team.

Lessons learned

From the FT point of view, a key takeaway was the importance of good communication to a successful project.

“It was a good showcase at both ends,” says Krum. “OpenAthens came mostly from the system administration perspective and we had a software engineering perspective, but we managed to solve all our challenges.”

OpenAthens’ willingness to communicate was appreciated.

“Any time we pinged them, they answered. And the workshop was crucial for us: we spent about four hours together in a virtual room – this was the best help we received.”

And OpenAthens, too, is learning for the future: the Financial Times have made helpful suggestions which have identified ways to help improve the documentation of Keystone – and help shape the direction of the software.

“Sincere and tremendous thanks for helping us out in this non-trivial transition. So happy to have reached this successful completion”

Wayfinder organizational discovery service

Free to all library and publisher platform providers

Simplify access to your online content

Why do you need Wayfinder? Publishers are losing revenue on subscriptions because it’s easier for people to get access to stolen content on pirate sites.

Why is this happening? Well, one of the main reasons is that the login experience for most people is very poor. For example, it’s very common for researchers to be confronted with a long list of identity federation or organisation names to choose from in order to login. This is where we can help.

Our organization discovery service ‘Wayfinder’ makes single sign-on a piece of cake.  Researchers can log-in simply and securely to access the many online resources their organization subscribes to, whilst keeping their privacy intact.

Choose Wayfinder to give people a simpler, better user experience – wherever they are in the world.

Need more support?

Our team of experts can help you to:

Comply with RA21 recommended practices ,

Implement and integrate with the SeamlessAccess service

Improve user experience and access to online content through our health check service.

Easily searchable Geo-location and a simple search enable people to easily find their home organization to log in.

La solución de autenticación rentable que prepara a la biblioteca de Gwanda State University para el futuro

29 September 2025

										• Faitai Bella Ballo, Product marketing officer

Esta joven universidad ha invertido en OpenAthens Connect para hacer realidad su visión.

Gwanda State University (GSU), en Zimbabue, se fundó en 2016 y ofrece una enseñanza basada en el patrimonio cultural y natural en ciencias animales y veterinarias, restauración de ecosistemas, ingeniería medioambiental, entre otras disciplinas. Recientemente, su biblioteca buscaba una solución de autenticación rentable que respaldara su estrategia de impulsar el aprendizaje, la investigación y la innovación de vanguardia de cara a 2030.

Amplios recursos bibliotecarios

La GSU cuenta con unos 500 estudiantes y casi 400 empleados. Todos dependen del variado contenido digital de la biblioteca, incluidas revistas, libros electrónicos, bases de datos, actas de congresos y videoconferencias que no solo son requeridos dentro de la biblioteca, sino también en los dos campus de la GSU, en sus hogares, en las residencias y cuando realizan prácticas. Pero sin una solución de autenticación, acceder a los recursos implicaba recordar numerosas contraseñas y afrontar una gran variedad de procesos de inicio de sesión que consumían mucho tiempo.

Era el momento de centrarse en las prioridades de la GSU para mejorar la experiencia de usuario y apoyar los nuevos enfoques de aprendizaje y enseñanza en un mundo cada vez más digital.

Solución de autenticación rentable

Como muchas universidades en África, la GSU quería adoptar una solución sencilla en lugar de una diseñada para organizaciones más grandes y complejas.

“Debemos ofrecer una experiencia de usuario ágil y sin interrupciones y apoyar el aprendizaje remoto y semipresencial", afirma Phillip Ndhlovu, subdirector de la biblioteca de la GSU.

“También necesitábamos reforzar la seguridad de la información mediante estándares de autenticación sólidos. Y, lo más importante, necesitábamos una solución más asequible que muchos de los productos disponibles en el mercado”.

Implementación sin interrupciones

Estudiaron cuidadosamente las opciones y nos alegra decir que eligieron la nuestra, porque es segura, fácil de usar y más asequible que otros productos comparables. Siguiendo la orientación que les facilitamos, el personal de Informática de la biblioteca de la GSU, con el apoyo del equipo de Informática de la universidad, gestionó por sí mismo la implementación de OpenAthens Connect,. El proceso fue sencillo, y las actualizaciones y el mantenimiento se gestionan habitualmente mediante lo que el personal bibliotecario describe como “comunicación y colaboración fluidas” entre la biblioteca, la editorial y nuestro servicio de asistencia.

Sus principales recomendaciones para instituciones que estén pensando en adoptar OpenAthens Connect son:

Involucrar desde el primer momento a tu departamento de tecnologías de la información y la comunicación (TIC) y explicar con claridad qué permisos o qué tipo de apoyo necesitarás.

Aprovechar la documentación detallada y los recursos de asistencia que ofrece OpenAthens para facilitar el proceso.

Comunicar al personal y a los usuarios los próximos cambios, de modo que sepan qué esperar y por qué es importante.

Ventajas

En la GSU consideran que OpenAthens Connect es la opción ideal para ellos. Disfrutan de una autenticación robusta, de alta calidad y rentable, que ofrece a los usuarios un acceso sin interrupciones a los recursos electrónicos con licencia, tanto dentro como fuera del campus. Y, lo que es fundamental, lo han logrado incluso con las limitaciones presupuestarias y de recursos que sufren muchas instituciones.

La biblioteca ha recopilado las opiniones de los usuarios a través de encuestas y grupos de debate. Los resultados son muy positivos, y un usuario lo resumió así:

“Es como si la biblioteca estuviera aquí mismo conmigo, incluso cuando estoy fuera del campus”.

“Los usuarios destacan la facilidad de acceso a los recursos desde fuera del campus con un único inicio de sesión y aprecian la experiencia de acceso uniforme en las distintas plataformas de las editoriales”

“Este tipo de comentarios nos ha confirmado que implementar OpenAthens Connect ha mejorado realmente el acceso y ha respondido a las necesidades de nuestros usuarios".

¡Confianza total en la solución! La autenticación eficiente ahora es invisible y totalmente fluida en el Oak Hill College

29 September 2025

										• Faitai Bella Ballo, Product marketing officer

En la entrevista de David Fordyce para el puesto de bibliotecario del centro, le preguntaron: "¿Cómo ofrecerías un servicio en el que los estudiantes pudieran acceder a todos nuestros recursos desde un único lugar?" Ahora los entrevistadores tienen su respuesta.

El Oak Hill es un centro especializado en Southgate, Londres, con una de las mejores bibliotecas de teología del sureste de Inglaterra, y está abierta las 24 horas del día, los 7 días de la semana. Cuenta con 55.000 recursos impresos y electrónicos de varios proveedores, y alrededor de 100 usuarios en línea, muchos de ellos residentes en el campus.

Una autenticación eficiente es esencial para la biblioteca y, hasta hace un par de años, se gestionaba mediante autenticación por IP o con el inicio de sesión en Google. La autenticación por IP resultaba válida para los usuarios en el campus, pero no satisfacía las necesidades de quienes estudiaban o trabajaban desde otros lugares.

Encontrar una solución de autenticación más eficiente

Resolver el problema de la autenticación fue el primer paso para responder a la pregunta de los entrevistadores. Pero, al tratarse de un centro pequeño y especializado, con un presupuesto modesto, la viabilidad económica era un factor esencial.

David consultó a otras bibliotecas del mismo sector que Oak Hill y comprobó que, por lo general, utilizaban autenticación mediante OpenAthens. Como resultado, el Oak Hill fue uno de los primeros en unirse al piloto de OpenAthens Connect, nuestro nuevo producto de funcionalidades básicas desarrollado para organizaciones menos complejas.

El proceso de configuración, afirma David, fue "sencillo". Simplemente recopiló una lista de sus proveedores de recursos y el producto OpenAthens Connect los configuró. Ahora, nuestra solución conecta a los usuarios de la biblioteca del centro con los recursos online a través de un nodo de identidades [identity hub], una opción económica y simple para instituciones más pequeñas.

Preparada para el futuro

La biblioteca de Oak Hill ha experimentado grandes mejoras gracias a ello, y se encuentra en una buena posición para avanzar aún más en los próximos meses.

"Los estudiantes de hoy esperan que todo funcione con un solo clic", comenta David.

Con nuestra solución de inicio de sesión único así es como funciona todo: los estudiantes y el personal pueden acceder a los recursos de la biblioteca estén donde estén aprendiendo o trabajando. David también ahorra mucho tiempo, porque antes tenía que dedicar largas horas a crear soluciones provisionales y gestionar inicios de sesión manuales.

Ahora la casilla de “autenticación eficiente” ya está marcada en la lista de tareas de David, y se encuentra en la fase dos de su plan.

En otoño de 2025, la biblioteca implementará EBSCO Discovery Service para reunir todos sus recursos en un único lugar.

"Identifiqué EBSCO como el mejor servicio de descubrimiento para nuestras necesidades especializadas, pero no tenía sentido contar con ello sin haber resuelto primero la autenticación", explica David.

Este nuevo avance hará posible una importante innovación para el centro: su primer curso totalmente online. En ese momento, Oak Hill pasará a utilizar nuestro producto premium OpenAthens Compass , que ofrece herramientas analíticas adicionales y otras funcionalidades. Compass será implementado por nuestro socio EBSCO como parte de su oferta de servicio de descubrimiento.

"Quiero contar con las funciones adicionales en ese momento", comenta David. "Estos productos pueden parecer difíciles de comprender, sobre todo la autenticación porque en gran medida es invisible. Pero ha sido posible lograr la aprobación de la compra porque los responsables del centro ven claramente los beneficios… y confían en que aún queden más por llegar".

Diseñamos OpenAthens Connect para cubrir un vacío y garantizar que todas las instituciones, independientemente de su tamaño y presupuesto, puedan disponer de una autenticación segura y fluida, sin complejidades técnicas. La experiencia de Oak Hill College con Connect demuestra lo fácil que resulta implementarlo y los numerosos beneficios que aporta.

Una solución de autenticación simplificada que da acceso a los estudiantes a recursos de calidad

29 September 2025

										• Faitai Bella Ballo, Product marketing officer

Derwentside College y el proyecto piloto de OpenAthens Connect

Hasta hace unos dos años, la biblioteca de Derwentside College utilizaba un sistema de autenticación basado en IP para dar acceso a los estudiantes a los recursos digitales. Eso significaba estar en el campus para poder utilizarlos. Cuando trabajaban fuera del campus, los estudiantes a menudo realizaban búsquedas online que los llevaban a contenidos de calidad inferior.

El piloto de OpenAthens Connect ofreció a la biblioteca de Derwentside la oportunidad perfecta de implementar una solución de autenticación segura y sencilla que funcionara en cualquier momento y lugar. OpenAthens Connect está diseñado para organizaciones menos complejas, como Derwentside. Ofrece una solución de acceso federado básico, rentable y centralizado. Habilitar el inicio de sesión único elimina la necesidad de múltiples y complejos procesos de inicio de sesión, haciendo que el uso de recursos digitales de alta calidad con licencia sea la opción más rápida y sencilla para los estudiantes.

La biblioteca de Derwentside College ofrece apoyo a aprendices y estudiantes en prácticas en distintos centros de trabajo a lo largo de gran parte de Inglaterra. Por eso necesita una solución de autenticación sencilla, eficaz y sin complicaciones.

Hasta hace poco, los 600 estudiantes de su campus en Consett, County Durham, utilizaban el sistema de autenticación basado en IP del centro para acceder a los recursos digitales, incluidos los libros electrónicos de la colección FE de Jisc. Los más de 2.500 estudiantes fuera del campus no tenían acceso a recursos online. Pero, a menudo, tampoco utilizaban los libros tradicionales del centro ni de sus proveedores de formación.

“Nos cuesta que los estudiantes usen libros; creen que Google tiene la respuesta para todo”, comenta Angela Cummings, responsable de aplicaciones en la nube y soporte de Informática en el campus de Consett, County Durham.

“Los estudiantes esperan trabajar en el ámbito digital, así que debemos darles los recursos adecuados: precisos, actualizados y con garantía de calidad.”

Autenticación simplificada en acción

Buscando una forma de autenticar a los usuarios que les facilitara aprender en cualquier momento y lugar, Derwentside se unió al piloto del nuevo producto de OpenAthens. Connect es nuestra solución de autenticación simplificada y rentable para organizaciones que no necesitan muchas opciones de personalización ni funciones avanzadas de análisis.

Angela comenta que se incorporaron al piloto con rapidez:

“Probablemente sea uno de los sistemas más fáciles que he tenido que configurar.”

No es de extrañar que algunos enlaces no funcionaran al principio. Pero todo fue resuelto rápidamente. Y como OpenAthens Connect está basado en la nube, el centro no tuvo que invertir en hardware ni software adicionales. Se integra fácilmente con su cuenta de Microsoft y nosotros nos encargamos del mantenimiento y las actualizaciones.

Ahorro de tiempo y costos

El equipo de la biblioteca de Derwentside College es reducido, por lo que es una gran ventaja que OpenAthens Connect les ahorre tiempo en la gestión de problemas informáticos: la solución de autenticación anterior provocaba a menudo fallos que resultaban frustrantes tanto para los estudiantes como al personal. Angela afirma que estos ahorros aumentarán a medida que la biblioteca refuerce su apuesta por lo digital en detrimento de los libros y revistas en papel. El centro tiene ahora la confianza para hacerlo, ya que dispone de un sistema de autenticación eficaz.

Mejora de la experiencia del usuario

Para los estudiantes de programas de formación profesional, OpenAthens Connect no solo es mejor que utilizar uno de los grandes buscadores comerciales, sino que también resulta más sencillo. Simplifica el descubrimiento. El inicio de sesión único los autentica y les ofrece acceso fluido a recursos de calidad y a sus propias búsquedas guardadas y anotadas para que puedan dar lo mejor de sí mismos.

¿A los estudiantes les gusta estas mejoras? Parece que sí: la prueba está en las herramientas de análisis integradas en Connect, como señala Angela:

“Podemos hacer un seguimiento del uso de los recursos. Sabemos, por ejemplo, que nuestros estudiantes de salud y asistencia social utilizan sus libros electrónicos en casi todas las sesiones.”

OverDrive content catalog joins OpenAthens Federation

14 October 2024

										• Jane Charlton, senior marketing manager - community and content

OverDrive, the world’s largest digital content provider extends access to education and healthcare organizations through OpenAthens.

We are excited to announce that OverDrive , the world’s largest digital content provider, has joined the OpenAthens access management federation . OverDrive took the business decision so it can more easily scale access to libraries in the education and healthcare sectors, creating a more seamless experience for users worldwide.

About OverDrive

Based in the US, the B-Corp Certified business works with more than 92,000 public libraries, schools, colleges and universities, and corporates in 115 countries. Its range of services include the Libby reading app , Sora reading platform and Kanopy streaming platform .

Importance of wellbeing resources for healthcare sector

Following the pandemic, more organizations are now investing in wellbeing and professional development resources to support their staff, reduce sickness absence and improve retention. OverDrive helps support education and healthcare organizations by delivering relevant content at point of need via the Libby reading app.

One reason for OverDrive’s move to the federated access model is to support the NHS , one of the world’s largest healthcare providers. Previously, OverDrive supported single sign-on via multiple one-to-one connections which large and complex organizations would struggle to support. OverDrive is increasingly being used by NHS trust libraries to provide wellbeing and professional development for staff to access anytime, anywhere.

Benefits of joining OpenAthens

Key benefits of joining OpenAthens include:

Scalable, seamless access to more industries and organizations through the OpenAthens access management federation

Improved security. OpenAthens helps protect published content by working with publishers and library organizations to identify and act on any signs of misuse.

Reduced overheads. Federated access removes the need for multiple one-to-one connections for sub-organizations.

Founder and CEO Steve Potash said:

“At OverDrive, we believe that knowledge and educational resources should be easily accessible. Joining the OpenAthens Federation is a natural extension of our mission to connect people with the content they need, when and where they need it. By streamlining access for organizations in the education and healthcare sectors, we’re not only enhancing user experience but also helping institutions like the NHS make meaningful impacts on their communities through seamless, secure access to digital resources.”

Working with 1:1 SAML connections

08 September 2022

										• Lauren Harding, Senior digital marketing manager

In October 2021, we presented the third instalment of our publisher webinar series called ‘Talkin ‘bout my federation’. We took a deep dive into the usage of 1:1 connections. If you haven’t watched the webinar yet, fear not – here’s a review!

What are 1:1 SAML connections?

Also referred to as bilateral or peer-to-peer connections, 1:1 SAML connections are flexible ways of connecting and sharing information between SAML-enabled systems. The benefit of this access method is that it can be used to connect Identity Providers (IdP) and Service Providers (SP) without the membership of any identity federation such as InCommon, UK Access Management Federation or Openathens.

1:1 connections are commonly used by customers that are logging into an internal service that has Shibboleth SP setup or by publishers that support SAML but have not joined a federation. IdP software can connect to multiple providers, whether in a federation or through 1:1 connections.

What are the disadvantages of using 1:1 SAML connections?

There are some reasons why you might not want to use a 1:1 connection. These connections can be more complex to set up and require technical knowledge and ongoing maintenance that not all library teams have. This in turn, means greater administrative and overhead costs. There is also the risk of disruptions in service due to metadata or certificate changes. The setup and maintenance are dependent on the IdP and SP co-operating with each other to configure the service, and there is no 3rd party assistance from the federation operator.

The publisher perspective

Publishers have additional considerations. For example, service providers must maintain each individual connection.

Sam commented:

“One publisher might have around 400 customers. To setup each of those customers as a 1:1 connection, you could be looking at 20 to 30 service tickets per day for up to four weeks.”

Federated access vs 1:1 SAML connections

Our webinar offers a helpful comparison between 1:1 connections and federated access.

“Using multiple 1:1 connections can feel like a spider web. With the OpenAthens Federation, service providers and identity providers only need to maintain a single connection to be part of a trusted network of entities,”

added Sam.

With 1:1 connections, the maintenance of the IdPs connection to the service is being managed with an individual person at each separate institution which is often not scalable. Establishing a connection via an identity federation means you only need to manage your connection to the federation, liaising with the federation operator only. This also provides access to a team of support specialists for customers and publishers alike.

Why join the OpenAthens Federation?

Most other identity federation are location and sector specific, meaning some IdPs are not eligible for membership. Our primary goal is providing single sign-on services and removing barriers to access. Our identity federation allows participation from any country or sector. Joining our federation potentially connects to you customers that you would otherwise need to establish 1:1 connections with. Find out who is already part of our federation, check out our federation member list.

We are advocates of federated access with over 25 years of experiencing liaising with SPs on behalf of thousands of organizations around the world. We understand the needs and expectations that they have. With this knowledge and experience, we provide advice and guidance to help you implement various functions including:

Authorization

Deep-linking

Attribute usage

Advice on the login experience for your users

Wrapping up the webinar, Lionel commented:

“We have about fifty highly trained IT professionals who make sure that the OpenAthens Federation is running smoothly at all times. The technical support team operates between 07:00 and 22:00 so that we can offer assistance to clients in international time zones. OpenAthens is truly an international federation with a client base across multiple sectors."

SPs using an existing SAML supported platform are able to join our federation with no need to install additional software.

Watch our webinar discussion in full on our YouTube channel

An assumed understanding of SAML

25 June 2020

										• Phil Leahy, key client services manager

My favorite session during our Access Lab 2020 conference was an admirably candid account of a release that included a change to the login journey on a publisher’s website. This caused more disruption than the publisher was comfortable with. One of the key lessons they shared was not to make assumptions about anything: your users, your customers, the validity of your ideas, or the place of your product within the scholarly ecosystem.

The open nature of this account chimed for me with an excellent book by Matthew Syed called Black Box Thinking. It’s about learning from failure without apportioning blame, and how learning from failure can drive innovation – because “we cannot grow unless we are prepared to learn from our mistakes”.

One theme of the book talks about the risks associated with “habits of assumed understanding”. Our service desk often deals with support tickets where assumptions about how access management should work are firmly entrenched. Here is one which crops up regularly.

SAML is an open standard, therefore I know how SAML works

We get this from publisher development teams. A lot. This is not to say they’re at fault for this view. There are a number of documentation articles that support that view. However, it often overlooks grey areas in the SAML specification . The Shibboleth open-source implementation of SAML was specified for this reason – to bring order and predictability to a secure method of exchanging authentication and authorization data. SAML needed operating instructions for true interoperability.

It has been my ‘privilege’ to read tortuous threads between publisher technical specialists and institutional network technicians trying to build a peer-to-peer SAML connection. Because that’s how SAML works, isn’t it? Or worse – a hapless librarian is put in the middle of the conversation. Significant effort is often spent trying to reach agreement on (say) the format of a NameID attribute to uniquely identify users whilst protecting privacy. And when this gets too difficult, they default to using an email address. Hmmm.

You want us to do that NOW?

The OpenAthens team have been resetting the expectations of publisher technical teams for years. Unfortunately, we sometimes discover these mismatched expectations rather late in the day. Sometimes that day is the publisher’s release day – which can make it a surprise with consequences.

Here are some of the issues we’ve seen in the last 12 – 18 months:

A publisher joins an identity federation having previously relied on IP recognition as its primary access route. But they did not update their subscription records with their customers’ federation IDs. Users can’t login.

A federated resource is upgraded and replaced – but the new resource is not registered in the federation(s) where its predecessor was available. Users can’t login.

A federated resource changes its WAYFless link syntax without advising their customers. Links registered in link resolvers and library management systems instantly become obsolete. Users can’t login.

At OpenAthens we are acutely aware that the login process is the final piece in a complex publishing workflow. We don’t want to distract a publisher’s development team from that important work. But we do ask you to keep us updated with your development timetables, and to make sure our service desk’s testing of your product’s login journey has a place on your project plan.

So keep talking to us . Without that dialogue, you could be building a beautiful palace on a sun-dappled island with no means of visiting it.

Nobody’s perfect

Some reading this might reasonably ask “and what about OpenAthens – surely you make incorrect assumptions too?” Yes, we do, and in the interests of fairness here is a recent one:

The COVID-19 situation caused us to review how we manage our administrator accounts, as almost all our customers now require access from home. Our development team worked quickly to build and release a change to the login process for administrators. We were pleased to get this enhancement out quickly to our customers. But everyone assumed someone else had briefed our service desk on how it worked and what questions they might expect to see. Oops.

I’ll close with a quote from Matthew Syed: “Learn from the mistakes of others. You can’t live long enough to make them all yourself.”

How can we help?

Get in touch to find out how OpenAthens can support you and your users

Federated access is the future of authentication

25 April 2023

										• Michael Smith, senior marketing officer

Libraries aren't just book-lined spaces anymore. With resources distributed across the web they're almost boundless. Their patrons could be just about anywhere too, accessing resources on a variety of devices. This means old access management methods don't pass muster, but federated access offers a better way. Our Principal technical consultant, Adam Snook, explains why...

Freedom to roam

What does federated single sign-on offer that library users don’t have with traditional single sign-on?

“If single sign-on provides library users with a smoother, more efficient journey around the byways of their institution’s systems and services, federated single sign-on takes them out on the open road,” says Adam. “In the OpenAthens Federation , each partner organization authenticates its own users and verifies their credentials to every other partner. It enables library patrons to roam through more resources more freely.”

User-friendly

Better still, it gives content providers opportunities to provide a richer user experience. As Adam says:

“Federated authentication makes it possible for content providers to create a secure, anonymized profile for users to track their interests and preferences. By default, OpenAthens does not release personal identifiable information, and librarians can choose how much to share. This option brings the possibility of user-friendly features like saved searches, annotation and suggestions for related content, as well as continual professional development (CPD)."

“And for library staff federated single sign-on means less admin. Because users have to remember fewer passwords staff spend less time on resets. At the same time, institutional security is improved; there’s less chance that poorly managed passwords will open systems up to attacks and data breaches. Users are also less likely to share their organisational credentials with others.”

With federated authentication, user identities are managed in a user directory, typically by IT. Usually, IT will set controls over how authentication works: if multi-factor authentication is enabled and who has access to which resources. They can also manage changes as people move through the organization. When you choose federated authentication your institution’s systems are generally better protected in the sense that they are in your control and you have full visibility. Compare this with having many accounts in third-party systems – in this case, you have neither of these things.

Federated authentication allows IT to do what it does best and means library staff can focus on supporting library patrons. That might be outreach or other work that improves the user experience, boosts library engagement and delivers a better return on investment.

Alternatives

“While federated access wins out on two fronts by enabling library users to do their work more easily and freeing up library staff to add value, not all content providers offer it,” comments Adam. “The most common alternative is IP recognition, which clearly has downsides with regard to remote access. This is where proxy services are commonly used.

“For an institution, self-hosting proxy servers can be hard work and time-consuming. Most librarians face a steep learning curve to make sure they can do it reliably. Not surprisingly, more and more are opting for a managed service instead.

“Certainly, at OpenAthens, growing numbers are signing up for our managed proxy service.  By taking on the complex parts of the job we bridge the gap between the library and IT, allowing them to focus on their core responsibilities. We enable library staff to manage their authentication costs and be more independent in how they manage library services.”

OpenAthens offers a quick and practical way to get serious about remote access. It future-proofs libraries through federated authentication, while also allowing access to content through the OpenAthens managed proxy. This allows libraries to enjoy some important benefits from both, including seamless access for users.

As well as a better, more personalized user experience, federated access offers enhanced privacy, while a proxy solution means users are simply less well-protected. For example, they may have to provide additional information to content providers such as an email address to do something as simple as save a search. With federated single sign-on the user’s anonymized identity is all that’s needed.

Future-proof

Adopting federated access will ensure your library can offer the freedom, choice and user experience that its users expect in a world where they use their own devices to study and work anywhere they want.

Which solution to choose? In terms of getting users to resources seamlessly they all do much the same thing. But in choosing the cloud-based OpenAthens federated access management solution you can avoid more of the grunt work. It integrates with multiple widely used systems and directories – so if you’re an ADFS, Microsoft Azure or G-Suite user, for example, there’s no problem.

We offer plenty of choice about how to onboard users for maximum efficiency and – crucially – our technical experts will work with you to decide the optimal solution for your organization. They’ll help you through the implementation too.

Want to know more about federated single sign-on?

Check out our recent webinar where we dive into what is federated single sign-on and the benefits it provides.
